end.title: Under the Wire
end.creator_credit: Michael Kronish, Tom Brisley, Danny Gabai, Arrow Media, VICE Media, BBC Storyville and Chris Martin
end.brief_description: On 12 February 2012, two journalists entered war-ravaged Syria. One of them was celebrated Sunday Times war correspondent, Marie Colvin. The other was photographer, Paul Conroy. Their aim was to cover the plight of Syrian civilians trapped in Homs, a city under siege and relentless military attack from the Syrian army. Only one of them returned.

links.description: A documentary about Marie Colvin was released in the same year, Under the Wire focuses on the reporter’s final assignment covering the siege of Homs in Syria. Colvin and colleague Remi Ochlik were killed in a targeted attack on a media centre.

end.title: Silvered Water
end.creator_credit: Proaction Film, Les Films d'ici, Ossama Mohammed and Wiam Bedirxan
end.headline_credit: France, Lebanon, Syrian Arab Republic and United States of America, 2014
end.brief_description: Shot by a reported “1,001 Syrians” according to the filmmakers, Silvered Water impressionistically documents the destruction and atrocities of the civil war through a combination of eye-witness accounts shot on mobile phones and posted to the internet, and footage shot by Bedirxan during the siege of Homs.

links.description: Silvered Water, directed by Ossama Mohammed and Wiam Simav Bedirxan, is compiled from footage filmed on mobile phones and uploaded to YouTube by anonymous users, creating a visual archive of the multiple experiences of people in Syria.
